abstract.text: No overview available.
Set the height of item(s) using layout constraints
Optionally specify for the height to match the width
(particularly useful where height is percentage-based).
Using
will create two constraints, one for
the width and one for the height.
Pin the queried items so that they stretch to fit their
parent/reference/guide between leading and trailing edges,
with optional insets (before/after).
Set the size of item(s) using layout constraints
Pin the queried items to all edges of their parent or reference
item, providing optional inset value. For more control over edge
and inset see other pin() method.
Spread queried items evenly along an axis (or axes) within their
parent/reference so that items are
to fit the available space
minus inter-item spacing and/or edge insets.
(Does not support randomization. Use Mutator if randomization is needed.)
Set the
origin of queried items via AutoLayout
Optionally provide percentile value for the items to be
positioned from origin relative to parent/reference.
To support both percentage-based values and additional constant
specify multiplier on chain and constant value on this method.
E.g.
Unlike other API, this strictly ignores layout direction
and sets a “left” constraint.
See pinning API which respect layout direction.
Center items horizontally relative to their parent or reference
item without affecting their current vertical position(s).
Value mutation affects offset only.
Wrapper for layout manipulation using autolayout constraints
on views and guides.
Pin to top edge if condition is true, otherwise
pin to bottom edge (with optional insets).
Update the queried item’s size to match the reference item (or parent).
Use this in combination with multiplier to size to a percentage
of the reference item or parent (or just use operator
with percentile values, e.g.
is a Swift framework for developing apps on iOS and iPadOS.
Disperse a
of items along both axes within parent/reference.
Specify the number of items for the first axis (width or height edge)
which are dispersed along that axis, and subsequently dispersed items
on the cross axis (width or height edge) such that all items will
be dispersed on both axis, potentially forming a “grid” or similar
dispersed structure.
Provide insets to control where the items start and/or end, or
omit insets to disperse the items evenly within the edges.
For example, omitting the insets provides even spacing before and
after items equal to the spacing between the items.
To pin items to the edges (with equal spacing) use inset of 0.0
or other specific value.
Without insets, if the items do not fit in their container they
will “spill over” but remain centered relative to the container.
In this case, insets may be provided to force the items to remain
within the container, in which case the items will overlap each other.
Optionally provide “grouper” trailing closure to further refine
how items should be grouped on the cross-axis (e.g. in the case of
using “width” (aka “horizontal”) the cross-axis for dispersion is “vertical”).
The closure is passed an item index and the current item and must return
a hashable value to logically group the items for dispersion on the
cross-axis. TIP: The hashable return value may also be an instance of
IndexedAlignment() for advanced post-grouping alignment. Example:
Pin the queried items to any edge or edges of the parent
or reference item, providing insets for each (dictionary).
Advanced pinning.
Pin the queried items so that they stretch to fit their
parent/reference/guide between top and bottom edges,
with optional insets (above/below).
Stretch the queried items to fit their parent/reference/guide
between leading and trailing edges, with optional insets (before/after).
Spread queried items evenly along horizontal axis within their
parent/reference so that items are
to fit the available space
minus inter-item spacing and/or edge insets.
(Does not support randomization. Use Mutator if randomization is needed.)
Stretch the queried items to fit to their parent or reference
item, providing optional inset value. For more control over edge
and inset see other pin() method. Optionally, provide
that should be stretched to fit.
Center items relative to their parent or reference item.
Optionally specify axis and/or offsets.
Value mutation affects offsets if provided.
Spread queried items evenly along vertical axis within their
parent/reference so that items are
to fit the available space
minus inter-item spacing and/or edge insets.
(Does not support randomization. Use Mutator if randomization is needed.)
Pin to left edge if condition is true, otherwise
pin to right edge (with optional insets).
Update the queried item’s width to match the reference item (or parent).
Use this in combination with multiplier to size to a percentage
of the reference item or parent (or just use operator
with percentile values, e.g.
Fit the queried items to fill their parent/reference/guide
according to specific area (top, middle, etc) with fractional
value and optional inset for the perpendicular sides.
Fractional value < 1.0 is relative percentage of parent
Fractional value >= 1.0 is absolute value in points.
NOTE: Calling this method on View or Guide item(s) implicitly
supports adding an optional flexible remainder area (via
Mutator “remainder{}”) which would be a sibling of the item(s)
and fill the remaining space within the parent.
Set the width of item(s) using layout constraints
Optionally specify for the height to match the width
which will create a square shape.
(particularly useful where width is percentage-based).
Using
will create two constraints, one for
the width and one for the height.
Center items vertically relative to their parent or reference
item without affecting their current horizontal position(s).
Value mutation affects offset only.
Update the queried item’s height to match the reference item (or parent).
Use this in combination with multiplier to size to a percentage
of the reference item or parent (or just use operator
with percentile values, e.g.
Stretch the queried items to fit their parent/reference/guide
between top and bottom edges, with optional insets (above/below).
Set the x/y origin, and width/height via AutoLayout.
Unlike other API, x value strictly ignores layout direction
and sets a “left” constraint.
Pin the queried items to any side or sides of the parent
or reference item, providing an optional inset value.
For more control over edge and inset see other pin() method.
See also convenience API pinHorizontally/Vertically.
Basic pinning.

Disperse queried items evenly along the horizontal axis within their parent.
Provide insets to control where the items start and/or end, or omit
both insets to disperse the items evenly within the edges.
For example to provide even spacing before and after items
equal to the spacing between the items, omit the insets.
To pin items to the edges (with equal spacing) use inset of 0.0.
Fit the queried items to fill their parent/reference/guide by
a percentage along vertical/horizontal axes or both.
Disperse queried items evenly along an axis within their parent.
Provide insets to control where the items start and/or end, or
omit both insets to disperse the items evenly within the edges.
For example to provide even spacing before and after items
equal to the spacing between the items, omit the insets.
To pin items to the edges (with equal spacing) use inset of 0.0.
Spread a
of items items evenly (or randomly) along both axes within
their parent/reference so that items are
to fit the available space
minus inter-item spacing and/or edge insets. Specify the number of items
for the first axis (width or height edge) to be spread along that axis,
and subsequently spread items on the cross axis (width or height
edge) such that all items will be spread on both axis, potentially forming
a “grid” or similar structure.
Use negative spacing to create overlap between items.
If the spacing exceeds the available space, items may disappear or
flow beyond their parent/reference.
Optionally provide “grouper” trailing closure to further refine
how items should be grouped on the cross-axis (e.g. in the case of
using “width” (aka “horizontal”) the cross-axis for dispersion is “vertical”).
The closure is passed an item index and the current item and must return
a hashable value to logically group the items for dispersion on the
cross-axis. TIP: The hashable return value may also be an instance of
IndexedAlignment() for advanced post-grouping alignment. Example:

both insets to disperse the items evenly within the edges.
For example to provide even spacing before and after items

To pin items to the edges (with equal spacing) use inset of 0.0.
